summary.text_en: Nikola Tesla invented the first practical 'AC Induction Motor' and the associated 'Polyphase System'. Before this, the industry was dominated by Edison's 'Direct Current' (DC), which could not be transmitted over long distances, and DC motors required high-maintenance 'brushes'. Tesla utilized the principle of the 'Rotating Magnetic Field' to design a motor that turned without physical contact (brushless). This invention solved the 'last mile' problem for AC, allowing it to power factories, winning the 'War of Currents' and establishing the foundation of the modern electric grid.

story.text_en: Tesla's inspiration came in a flash of insight while walking in a park in Budapest. As he recited poetry from Goethe's 'Faust', he visualized a 'Rotating Magnetic Field'. DC motors of the time needed 'brushes' to mechanically switch current direction. Tesla's idea: instead of changing the current on the rotor, change the magnetic field on the stator. He designed a system using 'polyphase' AC (currents out of step with each other) so that the magnetic field 'rotated' in space. The rotor, trying to 'catch up' with this field, would spin automatically. In 1888, he sold the patents to George Westinghouse, who used them to build the first major AC power plant at Niagara Falls.

fun_facts.text_en: To demonstrate the 'rotating magnetic field' to investors, Tesla performed the 'Egg of Columbus' trick: he put a copper egg on a table and turned on the coils. The egg spun and, due to the gyroscopic effect, stood up on its end.
To discredit Tesla's AC, Edison launched a dirty propaganda campaign, publicly electrocuting animals (including Topsy the elephant) to prove AC was 'too dangerous'. Tesla won anyway.

simple_explanation.text_en:
Before Tesla, electric motors were like a merry-go-round that needed someone (brushes) to physically push it every time it went around. It was messy and broke easily.
Tesla invented a 'ghost merry-go-round'. He put magnets around the outside and made their magnetic pull 'rotate' like a wave. The rotor in the middle didn't touch anything, but it started spinning to 'chase' the invisible magnetic field circling around it. Because there were no rubbing parts, it was incredibly durable and powerful.

applications.text_en: The induction motor is the workhorse of modern industry. Conveyor belts, pumps, fans, and heavy machinery are almost all powered by it.

applications.text_en: Tesla, Inc. is named after him. Its early cars (like the Model S) used an updated version of his 'AC induction motor'.

applications.text_en: Your washing machine, refrigerator compressor, and A/C fans all contain the motor Tesla invented.

impact.text_en: Tesla's AC motor was a core technology of the Second Industrial Revolution. It broke the distance limit of Edison's DC, allowing power to be transmitted efficiently from remote sources (like hydroelectric dams) to cities and factories hundreds of miles away. It laid the foundation for the modern 'Electric Grid', making electricity as ubiquitous as air and water.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Faraday (his 'electromagnetic induction' is the core physics of the motor, hence the name)
Maxwell (his field theory helped Tesla understand how magnetic fields behave in space)

influenced.contribution_en: George Westinghouse (bought Tesla's patents and built the Niagara Falls power plant, sealing the victory of AC)
The Modern Power Grid (built entirely on Tesla's polyphase AC system)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Nikola Tesla wired the world for 'AC' and gave it a beating 'heart' (the induction motor).

quiz.question_en: What major flaw of existing DC motors did Tesla's 'Induction Motor' solve?
options_en: DC motors needed 'brushes' and 'commutators' which sparked and wore out
quiz.explanation_en: Tesla used the 'rotating magnetic field' to induce current in the rotor, eliminating the need for physical contacts (brushes) to transfer electricity. This made the motor durable, efficient, and maintenance-free.
